26559177.projn:
PK-Pakistan: Promoting Girls' Education
            In Balochistan (Pgeb) -- P128096
26559177.trustfund:
TF012826-Promoting Girls Education in Balochistan,TF010459-Pakistan: Promoting Girls'
            Education in Balochistan

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Promoting Girls' Education
            In Balochistan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Promoting Girls'
            Education in Balochistan Project for Pakistan were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            communities’ strong sense of ownership of schools
            contributed to enhancing girls’ education. Recruiting female
            teachers from the own community contributed to increased
            comfort among community members and developed a great role
            model for girls. A community-led model of needs
            identification provides a cost-effective solution to new
            school establishment, which can be adopted in similar,
            sparsely-populated places. In Balochistan, where low
            population density and sparse population is a constraint for
            service delivery, the PGEB tackled the problem by soliciting
            applications from communities and surveying communities to
            verify the actual needs of the set criteria. This approach
            enabled fast establishment of schools in communities, which
            have commitment and willingness to contribute to education,
            and increased access of children to school. Flexibility of
            project design toward achievement of objectives and quick
            decisions will ensure timely implementation and maximization
            of benefits. When it was found that there would be savings
            due to cancellation of some activities for security reasons,
            the PMU took an initiative to revise the procurement plan
            and the GoB made a quick decision to reallocate funds.
            Additional outputs, as listed in annex two, contributed to
            increase the beneficiaries and project outcomes by
            efficiently utilizing the available funds.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Promoting Girl's Education
            in Balochistan Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Promoting Girl's Education in Balochistan Project for
            Pakistan is to improve access to education and retention of
            children in schools, with a special emphasis on girls, in
            the province of Balochistan. Negative impacts includes:
            zoning and land use planning; water and soil contamination;
            noise and air pollution hazardous substances;
            destruction/disruption of land and vegetation; loss of
            cultural property; and expropriation and social disturbance.
            Mitigation measures includes: 1) noise prevention and
            mitigation measures should be applied where predicted or
            measured noise impacts from a project facility or operations
            exceed the applicable noise level guideline at the most
            sensitive point of reception; 2) provisions for adequate
            budget and satisfactory institutional arrangements to
            monitor the effective implementation of environmental and
            social mitigation measures; 3) institutions/departments
            responsible for implementing mitigation measures and for
            monitoring their performance should be clearly identified.
            Additionally, roles and responsibilities of various
            personnel in these departments should be clearly specified;
            4) secure the site to prevent any damage or loss of
            removable objects. In cases of removable antiquities or
            sensitive remains, a night guard shall be present until the
            responsible local authorities and the Ministry in charge of
            Department of Archaeology and Museums take over; and 5)
            construction work could resume only after permission is
            given from the responsible local authorities and the
            Ministry in charge of Department of Archaeology and Museums
            concerning safeguard of the heritage.
